stem: A 19-year-old client is being monitored for potential compartment syndrome after a crush injury to the right forearm. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: The client's right forearm pressure is rising rapidly, now at 38 mmHg. Severe pain is reported with passive finger extension.
Background: The client sustained a crushing injury to the right radius and ulna from a heavy machinery accident earlier today.
Assessment: At 08:00, the intercompartmental pressure was 12 mmHg. At 09:00, it rose to 24 mmHg. At 10:00, the pressure is now 38 mmHg. The hand is pink with palpable pulses. Pain is 10/10 despite fentanyl administration.
Recommendation: Prepare for emergent fasciotomy. Continue frequent monitoring of intercompartmental pressures and neurovascular status. Maintain NPO status.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 142/88, HR 112, RR 20. Pain scale 10/10 despite fentanyl.

actionOptions.text: Prepare the client for emergent fasciotomy
Apply a tight elastic bandage to the arm

rationale.correct: With a recorded pressure of 38 mmHg, the client is experiencing acute compartment syndrome (c1). Normal compartment pressure is 0-8 mmHg; pressures sustained above 30 mmHg (or within 30 mmHg of the diastolic blood pressure) usually require a fasciotomy (a1). The nurse must maintain NPO status (a2) in preparation for surgery. Monitoring pressures (p1) and neurovascular status (p2) continues until the patient enters the OR.
clinicalPearls: Manual pressure measurement (Stryker device) is the gold standard for diagnosing compartment syndrome when clinical signs are ambiguous.
Never wait for pulselessness—this is the very last sign and indicates muscle death has already occurred.
The passive stretch test (extending the fingers or toes) is the most sensitive clinical indicator.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking 38 mmHg is only a little high.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember the number 30. If the pressure is ≥30, the cells are being squeezed and oxygen cannot get in. It is a surgical emergency.

mnemonic.title: 6 P's of Compartment Syndrome
mnemonic.expansion: Pain (out of proportion), Pallor, Paresthesia, Pulselessness, Paralysis, Pressure (increased)
